element.definition: The Measure resource provides the definition of a quality measure.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where(((id.exists() and ('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url)))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(uri) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management
Stratifier SHALL be either a single criteria or a set of criteria components

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: IETF language tag

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

constraint.human: Containing new R4B resources within R4 resources may cause interoperability issues if instances are shared with R4 systems
constraint.expression: ($this is Citation or $this is Evidence or $this is EvidenceReport or $this is EvidenceVariable or $this is MedicinalProductDefinition or $this is PackagedProductDefinition or $this is AdministrableProductDefinition or $this is Ingredient or $this is ClinicalUseDefinition or $this is RegulatedAuthorization or $this is SubstanceDefinition or $this is SubscriptionStatus or $this is SubscriptionTopic) implies (%resource is Citation or %resource is Evidence or %resource is EvidenceReport or %resource is EvidenceVariable or %resource is MedicinalProductDefinition or %resource is PackagedProductDefinition or %resource is AdministrableProductDefinition or %resource is Ingredient or %resource is ClinicalUseDefinition or %resource is RegulatedAuthorization or %resource is SubstanceDefinition or %resource is SubscriptionStatus or %resource is SubscriptionTopic)

element.short: Canonical identifier for this measure, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this measure when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this measure is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the measure is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the measure to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this measure when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this measure outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the measure when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the measure author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence. To provide a version consistent with the Decision Support Service specification, use the format Major.Minor.Revision (e.g. 1.0.0). For more information on versioning knowledge assets, refer to the Decision Support Service specification. Note that a version is required for non-experimental active artifacts.
element.comment: There may be different measure instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the measure with the format [url]|[version].

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A natural language name identifying the measure. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the measure.
element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An explanatory or alternate title for the measure giving additional information about its content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The status of this measure. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.comment: Allows filtering of measures that are appropriate for use versus not.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration

binding.description: The lifecycle status of an artifact.

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this measure is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comment: Allows filtering of measures that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level measure.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: E.g. Patient, Practitioner, RelatedPerson, Organization, Location, Device
element.definition: The intended subjects for the measure. If this element is not provided, a Patient subject is assumed, but the subject of the measure can be anything.
element.comment: The subject of the measure is critical in interpreting the criteria definitions, as the logic in the measures is evaluated with respect to a particular subject. This corresponds roughly to the notion of a Compartment in that it limits what content is available based on its relationship to the subject. In CQL, this corresponds to the context declaration.
element.meaningWhenMissing: Patient

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The possible types of subjects for a measure (E.g. Patient, Practitioner, Organization, Location, etc.).

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the measure was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the measure changes.
element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the measure. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name of the publisher (organization or individual)
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the measure.
element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the measure is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the measure. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the measure. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the measure.  May also allow for contact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Natural language description of the measure
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the measure from a consumer's perspective.
element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the measure was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the measure as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the measure is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the measure was created).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The context that the content is intended to support
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate measure instances.
element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the measure is intended to be used.
element.comment: It may be possible for the measure to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Countries and regions within which this artifact is targeted for use.

element.definition: Explanation of why this measure is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the measure. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this measure.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Describes the clinical usage of the measure
element.definition: A detailed description, from a clinical perspective, of how the measure is used.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A copyright statement relating to the measure and/or its contents. Copyright statements are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the measure.
element.requirements: Consumers must be able to determine any legal restrictions on the use of the measure and/or its content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the measure was approved by publisher
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the measure was last reviewed
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When the measure is expected to be used
element.definition: The period during which the measure content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.comment: The effective period for a measure  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the measure are or are expected to be used instead.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The category of the measure, such as Education, Treatment, Assessment, etc.
element.definition: Descriptive topics related to the content of the measure. Topics provide a high-level categorization grouping types of measures that can be useful for filtering and searching.
element.requirements: Repositories must be able to determine how to categorize the measure so that it can be found by topical searches.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: High-level categorization of the definition, used for searching, sorting, and filtering.

element.definition: An individiual or organization primarily involved in the creation and maintenance of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for internal coherence of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization primarily responsible for review of some aspect of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An individual or organization responsible for officially endorsing the content for use in some setting.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Related artifacts such as additional documentation, justification, or bibliographic references.
element.comment: Each related artifact is either an attachment, or a reference to another resource, but not both.
element.requirements: Measures must be able to provide enough information for consumers of the content (and/or interventions or results produced by the content) to be able to determine and understand the justification for and evidence in support of the content.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A reference to a Library resource containing the formal logic used by the measure.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Disclaimer for use of the measure or its referenced content
element.definition: Notices and disclaimers regarding the use of the measure or related to intellectual property (such as code systems) referenced by the measure.
element.requirements: Some organizations require that notices and disclosures be included when publishing measures that reference their intellecutal property.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Indicates how the calculation is performed for the measure, including proportion, ratio, continuous-variable, and cohort. The value set is extensible, allowing additional measure scoring types to be represented.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The scoring type of the measure.

element.definition: If this is a composite measure, the scoring method used to combine the component measures to determine the composite score.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The composite scoring method of the measure.

element.definition: Indicates whether the measure is used to examine a process, an outcome over time, a patient-reported outcome, or a structure measure such as utilization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of measure (includes codes from 2.16.840.1.113883.1.11.20368).

element.short: How risk adjustment is applied for this measure
element.definition: A description of the risk adjustment factors that may impact the resulting score for the measure and how they may be accounted for when computing and reporting measure results.
element.comment: Describes the method of adjusting for clinical severity and conditions present at the start of care that can influence patient outcomes for making valid comparisons of outcome measures across providers. Indicates whether a measure is subject to the statistical process for reducing, removing, or clarifying the influences of confounding factors to allow for more useful comparisons.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: How is rate aggregation performed for this measure
element.definition: Describes how to combine the information calculated, based on logic in each of several populations, into one summarized result.
element.comment: The measure rate for an organization or clinician is based upon the entitiesâ€™ aggregate data and summarizes the performance of the entity over a given time period (e.g., monthly, quarterly, yearly). The aggregated data are derived from the results of a specific measure algorithm and, if appropriate, the application of specific risk adjustment models.  Can also be used to describe how to risk adjust the data based on supplemental data elements described in the eMeasure (e.g., pneumonia hospital measures antibiotic selection in the ICU versus non-ICU and then the roll-up of the two). This could be applied to aggregated cohort measure definitions (e.g., CDC's aggregate reporting for TB at the state level).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Detailed description of why the measure exists
element.definition: Provides a succinct statement of the need for the measure. Usually includes statements pertaining to importance criterion: impact, gap in care, and evidence.
element.requirements: Measure developers need to be able to provide a detailed description of the purpose of the measure. This element provides detailed rationale, where the purpose element provides a summary of the rationale.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Provides a summary of relevant clinical guidelines or other clinical recommendations supporting the measure.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Information on whether an increase or decrease in score is the preferred result (e.g., a higher score indicates better quality OR a lower score indicates better quality OR quality is within a range).
element.requirements: Measure consumers and implementers must be able to determine how to interpret a measure score.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Observation values that indicate what change in a measurement value or score is indicative of an improvement in the measured item or scored issue.

element.short: Defined terms used in the measure documentation
element.definition: Provides a description of an individual term used within the measure.
element.requirements: Measure developers must be able to provide precise definitions of terms used within measure descriptions and guidance to help communicate the intent of the measure.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Additional guidance for the measure including how it can be used in a clinical context, and the intent of the measure.
element.requirements: Measure developers must be able to provide additional guidance for implementers to understand the intent with greater specificity than that provided in the population criteria of the measure. This element provides detailed guidance, where the usage element provides a summary of the guidance.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A group of population criteria for the measure.

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

element.short: A request for a service to be performed
element.definition: A record of a request for service such as diagnostic investigations, treatments, or operations to be performed.

If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where(((id.exists() and ('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url)))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(uri) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management
orderDetail SHALL only be present if code is present

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: IETF language tag

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

constraint.human: Containing new R4B resources within R4 resources may cause interoperability issues if instances are shared with R4 systems

element.definition: Identifiers assigned to this order instance by the orderer and/or the receiver and/or order fulfiller.
element.comment: The identifier.type element is used to distinguish between the identifiers assigned by the orderer (known as the 'Placer' in HL7 v2) and the producer of the observations in response to the order (known as the 'Filler' in HL7 v2).  For further discussion and examples see the resource notes section below.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this ServiceRequest.
element.comment: Note: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)).  It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types.  For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this ServiceRequest.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Plan/proposal/order fulfilled by this request.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The request takes the place of the referenced completed or terminated request(s).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A shared identifier common to all service requests that were authorized more or less simultaneously by a single author, representing the composite or group identifier.
element.comment: Requests are linked either by a "basedOn" relationship (i.e. one request is fulfilling another) or by having a common requisition. Requests that are part of the same requisition are generally treated independently from the perspective of changing their state or maintaining them after initial creation.
element.requirements: Some business processes need to know if multiple items were ordered as part of the same "requisition" for billing or other purposes.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: draft | active | on-hold | revoked | completed | entered-in-error | unknown
element.definition: The status of the order.
element.comment: The status is generally fully in the control of the requester - they determine whether the order is draft or active and, after it has been activated, competed, cancelled or suspended. States relating to the activities of the performer are reflected on either the corresponding event (see [Event Pattern](event.html) for general discussion) or using the [Task](task.html) resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because it is a status element that contains status entered-in-error which means that the resource should not be treated as valid

binding.description: The status of a service order.

element.short: proposal | plan | directive | order | original-order | reflex-order | filler-order | instance-order | option
element.definition: Whether the request is a proposal, plan, an original order or a reflex order.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the intent alters when and how the resource is actually applicable.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element changes the interpretation of all descriptive attributes. For example "the time the request is recommended to occur" vs. "the time the request is authorized to occur" or "who is recommended to perform the request" vs. "who is authorized to perform the request

binding.description: The kind of service request.

element.definition: A code that classifies the service for searching, sorting and display purposes (e.g. "Surgical Procedure").
element.comment: There may be multiple axis of categorization depending on the context or use case for retrieving or displaying the resource.  The level of granularity is defined by the category concepts in the value set.
element.requirements: Used for filtering what service request are retrieved and displayed.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Classification of the requested service.

element.definition: Indicates how quickly the ServiceRequest should be addressed with respect to other requests.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If missing, this task should be performed with normal priority

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Identifies the level of importance to be assigned to actioning the request.

element.short: True if service/procedure should not be performed
element.definition: Set this to true if the record is saying that the service/procedure should NOT be performed.
element.comment: In general, only the code and timeframe will be present, though occasional additional qualifiers such as body site or even performer could be included to narrow the scope of the prohibition.  If the ServiceRequest.code and ServiceRequest.doNotPerform both contain negation, that will reinforce prohibition and should not have a double negative interpretation.
element.requirements: Used for do not ambulate, do not elevate head of bed, do not flush NG tube, do not take blood pressure on a certain arm, etc.
element.meaningWhenMissing: If missing, the request is a positive request e.g. "do perform"

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: If true this element negates the specified action. For Example,  instead of a request for a procedure, it is a request for the procedure to not occur.

element.definition: A code that identifies a particular service (i.e., procedure, diagnostic investigation, or panel of investigations) that have been requested.
element.comment: Many laboratory and radiology procedure codes embed the specimen/organ system in the test order name, for example,  serum or serum/plasma glucose, or a chest x-ray. The specimen might not be recorded separately from the test code.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes for tests or services that can be carried out by a designated individual, organization or healthcare service.  For laboratory, LOINC is  (preferred)[http://build.fhir.org/terminologies.html#preferred] and a valueset using LOINC Order codes is available.

element.definition: Additional details and instructions about the how the services are to be delivered.   For example, and order for a urinary catheter may have an order detail for an external or indwelling catheter, or an order for a bandage may require additional instructions specifying how the bandage should be applied.
element.comment: For information from the medical record intended to support the delivery of the requested services, use the `supportingInformation` element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codified order entry details which are based on order context.

element.definition: An amount of service being requested which can be a quantity ( for example $1,500 home modification), a ratio ( for example, 20 half day visits per month), or a range (2.0 to 1.8 Gy per fraction).
element.requirements: When ordering a service the number of service items may need to be specified separately from the the service item.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Individual or Entity the service is ordered for
element.definition: On whom or what the service is to be performed. This is usually a human patient, but can also be requested on animals, groups of humans or animals, devices such as dialysis machines, or even locations (typically for environmental scans).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Encounter in which the request was created
element.definition: An encounter that provides additional information about the healthcare context in which this request is made.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date/time at which the requested service should occur.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: If a CodeableConcept is present, it indicates the pre-condition for performing the service.  For example "pain", "on flare-up", etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded concept identifying the pre-condition that should hold prior to performing a procedure.  For example "pain", "on flare-up", etc.

element.definition: When the request transitioned to being actionable.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The individual who initiated the request and has responsibility for its activation.
element.comment: This not the dispatcher, but rather who is the authorizer.  This element is not intended to handle delegation which would generally be managed through the Provenance resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Desired type of performer for doing the requested service.
element.comment: This is a  role, not  a participation type.  In other words, does not describe the task but describes the capacity.  For example, â€œcompounding pharmacyâ€, â€œpsychiatristâ€ or â€œinternal referralâ€.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as "Primary physician", "Team coordinator", "Caregiver", etc.

element.definition: The desired performer for doing the requested service.  For example, the surgeon, dermatopathologist, endoscopist, etc.
element.comment: If multiple performers are present, it is interpreted as a list of *alternative* performers without any preference regardless of order.  If order of preference is needed use the [request-performerOrder extension](extension-request-performerorder.html).  Use CareTeam to represent a group of performers (for example, Practitioner A *and* Practitioner B).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The preferred location(s) where the procedure should actually happen in coded or free text form. E.g. at home or nursing day care center.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A location type where services are delivered.

element.definition: A reference to the the preferred location(s) where the procedure should actually happen. E.g. at home or nursing day care center.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: An explanation or justification for why this service is being requested in coded or textual form.   This is often for billing purposes.  May relate to the resources referred to in `supportingInfo`.
element.comment: This element represents why the referral is being made and may be used to decide how the service will be performed, or even if it will be performed at all.   Use `CodeableConcept.text` element if the data is free (uncoded) text as shown in the [CT Scan example](servicerequest-example-di.html).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: SNOMED CT Condition/Problem/Diagnosis Codes

element.definition: Indicates another resource that provides a justification for why this service is being requested.   May relate to the resources referred to in `supportingInfo`.
element.comment: This element represents why the referral is being made and may be used to decide how the service will be performed, or even if it will be performed at all.    To be as specific as possible,  a reference to  *Observation* or *Condition* should be used if available.  Otherwise when referencing  *DiagnosticReport*  it should contain a finding  in `DiagnosticReport.conclusion` and/or `DiagnosticReport.conclusionCode`.   When using a reference to *DocumentReference*, the target document should contain clear findings language providing the relevant reason for this service request.  Use  the CodeableConcept text element in `ServiceRequest.reasonCode` if the data is free (uncoded) text as shown in the [CT Scan example](servicerequest-example-di.html).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Insurance plans, coverage extensions, pre-authorizations and/or pre-determinations that may be needed for delivering the requested service.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Additional clinical information about the patient or specimen that may influence the services or their interpretations.     This information includes diagnosis, clinical findings and other observations.  In laboratory ordering these are typically referred to as "ask at order entry questions (AOEs)".  This includes observations explicitly requested by the producer (filler) to provide context or supporting information needed to complete the order. For example,  reporting the amount of inspired oxygen for blood gas measurements.
element.comment: To represent information about how the services are to be delivered use the `instructions` element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: One or more specimens that the laboratory procedure will use.
element.comment: Many diagnostic procedures need a specimen, but the request itself is not actually about the specimen. This element is for when the diagnostic is requested on already existing specimens and the request points to the specimen it applies to.    Conversely, if the request is entered first with an unknown specimen, then the [Specimen](specimen.html) resource points to the ServiceRequest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Anatomic location where the procedure should be performed. This is the target site.
element.comment: Only used if not implicit in the code found in ServiceRequest.code.  If the use case requires BodySite to be handled as a separate resource instead of an inline coded element (e.g. to identify and track separately)  then use the standard extension [procedure-targetBodyStructure](extension-procedure-targetbodystructure.html).
element.requirements: Knowing where the procedure is performed is important for tracking if multiple sites are possible.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: SNOMED CT Body site concepts

element.definition: Any other notes and comments made about the service request. For example, internal billing notes.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Instructions in terms that are understood by the patient or consumer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Key events in the history of the request.
element.comment: This might not include provenances for all versions of the request â€“ only those deemed â€œrelevantâ€ or important.This SHALL NOT include the Provenance associated with this current version of the resource.  (If that provenance is deemed to be a â€œrelevantâ€ change, it will need to be added as part of a later update.  Until then, it can be queried directly as the Provenance that points to this version using _revincludeAll Provenances should have some historical version of this Request as their subject.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Represents a defined collection of entities that may be discussed or acted upon collectively but which are not expected to act collectively, and are not formally or legally recognized; i.e. a collection of entities that isn't an Organization.
element.comment: If both Group.characteristic and Group.member are present, then the members are the individuals who were found who met the characteristic.  It's possible that there might be other candidate members who meet the characteristic and aren't (yet) in the list.  All members SHALL have the listed characteristics.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where(((id.exists() and ('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url)))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(uri) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management
Can only have members if group is "actual"

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: IETF language tag

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

constraint.human: Containing new R4B resources within R4 resources may cause interoperability issues if instances are shared with R4 systems

element.requirements: Allows the group to be referenced from external specifications.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Whether this group's record is in active use
element.definition: Indicates whether the record for the group is available for use or is merely being retained for historical purposes.
element.requirements: Need to be able to mark a group record as not to be used because it was created in error or is otherwise no longer available (e.g. a herd that no longer exists).
element.meaningWhenMissing: This resource is generally assumed to be active if no value is provided for the active element

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: person | animal | practitioner | device | medication | substance
element.definition: Identifies the broad classification of the kind of resources the group includes.
element.comment: Group members SHALL be of the appropriate resource type (Patient for person or animal; or Practitioner, Device, Medication or Substance for the other types.).
element.requirements: Identifies what type of resources the group is made up of.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Types of resources that are part of group.

element.definition: If true, indicates that the resource refers to a specific group of real individuals.  If false, the group defines a set of intended individuals.
element.requirements: There are use-cases for groups that define specific collections of individuals, and other groups that define "types" of intended individuals.  The requirements for both kinds of groups are similar, so we use a single resource, distinguished by this flag.

element.definition: Provides a specific type of resource the group includes; e.g. "cow", "syringe", etc.
element.comment: This would generally be omitted for Person resources.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Kind of particular resource; e.g. cow, syringe, lake, etc.

element.definition: A label assigned to the group for human identification and communication.
element.requirements: Used to identify the group in human communication.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A count of the number of resource instances that are part of the group.
element.comment: Note that the quantity may be less than the number of members if some of the members are not active.
element.requirements: Group size is a common defining characteristic.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Entity that is the custodian of the Group's definition
element.definition: Entity responsible for defining and maintaining Group characteristics and/or registered members.
element.comment: This does not strictly align with ownership of a herd or flock, but may suffice to represent that relationship in simple cases. More complex cases will require an extension.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Include / Exclude group members by Trait

element.comment: All the identified characteristics must be true for an entity to a member of the group.
element.requirements: Needs to be a generic mechanism for identifying what individuals can be part of a group.

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

binding.description: IETF language tag

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

element.definition: Business identifiers assigned to this family member history by the performer or other systems which remain constant as the resource is updated and propagates from server to server.
element.comment: This is a business identifier, not a resource identifier (see [discussion](resource.html#identifiers)).  It is best practice for the identifier to only appear on a single resource instance, however business practices may occasionally dictate that multiple resource instances with the same identifier can exist - possibly even with different resource types.  For example, multiple Patient and a Person resource instance might share the same social insurance number.
element.requirements: Allows identification of the family member history as it is known by various participating systems and in a way that remains consistent across servers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The URL pointing to a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this FamilyMemberHistory.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The URL pointing to an externally maintained protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this FamilyMemberHistory.
element.comment: This might be an HTML page, PDF, etc. or could just be a non-resolvable URI identifier.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A code specifying the status of the record of the family history of a specific family member.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains codes that mark the resource as not currently valid.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labelled as a modifier because it is a status element that contains status entered-in-error which means that the resource should not be treated as valid

binding.description: A code that identifies the status of the family history record.

element.definition: Describes why the family member's history is not available.
element.requirements: This is a separate element to allow it to have a distinct binding from reasonCode.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes describing the reason why a family member's history is not available.

element.definition: The person who this history concerns.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: When history was recorded or last updated
element.definition: The date (and possibly time) when the family member history was recorded or last updated.
element.comment: This should be captured even if the same as the date on the List aggregating the full family history.
element.requirements: Allows determination of how current the summary is.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: This will either be a name or a description; e.g. "Aunt Susan", "my cousin with the red hair".
element.requirements: Allows greater ease in ensuring the same person is being talked about.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The type of relationship this person has to the patient (father, mother, brother etc.).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the related person being described in the family member history.

element.definition: The birth sex of the family member.
element.comment: This element should ideally reflect whether the individual is genetically male or female.  However, as reported information based on the knowledge of the patient or reporting friend/relative, there may be situations where the reported sex might not be totally accurate.  E.g. 'Aunt Sue' might be XY rather than XX.  Questions soliciting this information should be phrased to encourage capture of genetic sex where known.  However, systems performing analysis should also allow for the possibility of imprecision with this element.
element.requirements: Not all relationship codes imply sex and the relative's sex can be relevant for risk assessments.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes describing the sex assigned at birth as documented on the birth registration.

element.definition: The actual or approximate date of birth of the relative.
element.requirements: Allows calculation of the relative's age.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The age of the relative at the time the family member history is recorded.
element.comment: use estimatedAge to indicate whether the age is actual or not.
element.requirements: While age can be calculated from date of birth, sometimes recording age directly is more natural for clinicians.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: If true, indicates that the age value specified is an estimated value.
element.comment: This element is labeled as a modifier because the fact that age is estimated can/should change the results of any algorithm that calculates based on the specified age.
element.requirements: Clinicians often prefer to specify an estimaged age rather than an age range.
element.meaningWhenMissing: It is unknown whether the age is an estimate or not

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: Deceased flag or the actual or approximate age of the relative at the time of death for the family member history record.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Why was family member history performed?
element.definition: Describes why the family member history occurred in coded or textual form.
element.comment: Textual reasons can be captured using reasonCode.text.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes indicating why the family member history was done.

element.short: Why was family member history performed?
element.definition: Indicates a Condition, Observation, AllergyIntolerance, or QuestionnaireResponse that justifies this family member history event.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: This property allows a non condition-specific note to the made about the related person. Ideally, the note would be in the condition property, but this is not always possible.

element.short: Canonical identifier for this activity definition, represented as a URI (globally unique)
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this activity definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this activity definition is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the activity definition is stored on different servers.
element.comment:
Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred.  Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.

The determination of when to create a new version of a resource (same url, new version) vs. defining a new artifact is up to the author.  Considerations for making this decision are found in [Technical and Business Versions](resource.html#versions). 

In some cases, the resource can no longer be found at the stated url, but the url itself cannot change. Implementations can use the [meta.source](resource.html#meta) element to indicate where the current master source of the resource can be found.
element.requirements: Allows the activity definition to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Additional identifier for the activity definition
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this activity definition when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.comment: Typically, this is used for identifiers that can go in an HL7 V3 II (instance identifier) data type, and can then identify this activity definition outside of FHIR, where it is not possible to use the logical URI.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable business identifiers to be easily associated with the module.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Business version of the activity definition
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the activity definition when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the activity definition author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence. To provide a version consistent with the Decision Support Service specification, use the format Major.Minor.Revision (e.g. 1.0.0). For more information on versioning knowledge assets, refer to the Decision Support Service specification. Note that a version is required for non-experimental active assets.
element.comment: There may be different activity definition instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the activity definition with the format [url]|[version].

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this activity definition (computer friendly)
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the activity definition. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Name for this activity definition (human friendly)

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Subordinate title of the activity definition

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Type of individual the activity definition is intended for

The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the activity definition. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the activity definition is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the activity definition was created).

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management

element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: IETF language tag

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.
